author: Unreal Engine
description:
Watch this video from the ‘Motion Design in Unreal Engine’ series, in which Nick Jushchyshyn (AKA Pixel Prof) explores the creation of materials for motion graphics in UE 5.6.

You’ll get a look at how to:

Create new materials
Add textures and effects
Animate parameters 
And more

Don’t miss the next instalment of this Motion Design tutorial series! To learn more about Motion Design in Unreal Engine, check out the Epic Developer Community: https://dev.epicgames.com/documentation/unreal-engine/motion-design-in-unreal-engine

#MotionDesign, #Materials, #UnrealEngine, #UE5, #PixelProf
title: Motion Design in Unreal Engine, Episode 06: Materials

author: Unreal Engine
description:
Crocs, Versace, and WWE have already integrated their brands into popular Fortnite islands and experiences. In this session, Ryan Norrington of Metavision gives some of the hard-won insights from these integrations, and makes the case for financing more risks like these as part of a brand's creative process.

As a central part of UK broadcaster ITV, Metavision brings a unique perspective to this session. Find out what worked in 2024 brand integrations, and learn how creators can gain an appreciation of the media value of their audience. Attendees will leave with an understanding of how they can take steps toward tackling more ambitious game design, and take more risks in the creative process.
title: Unlocking the Value of Fortnite Audiences With Sponsors | Unreal Fest Orlando 2025

author: Unreal Engine
description:
A big thank you to those who joined our talk on Rigging and we're proud to have sponsored the Society for Game Cinematics!

You could be part of the future of game cinematics too, learn more about animating in Unreal Engine here: unrealengine.com/animation
title: We had a blast at SIGGRAPH celebrating creators and empowering them to innovate 🎞️

author: Unreal Engine
description:
One of the main challenges of automotive design is visualizing cars quickly in different markets and environments. With the use of the Procedural Content Generation Framework (PCG) in Unreal Engine, real-time rendering environments can be rapidly updated and changed to produce content suitable for design reviews.

In this session, Jack Gullen of McLaren describes how to quickly set up a car using the Control Rig system introduced in Unreal 5.4, and bring this setup into an environment with roads and scenery generated with the PCG using Quixel assets. Work with a world that shifts between different seasons and biomes (forest/desert) before assets such as surrounding foliage are fine-tuned to create automotive media. 

Although the steps shown in this session pertain to automotive visualization, the workflow can be adapted to many other industries.
title: Procedural Worlds by McLaren: Automotive Visualization with PCG Content | Unreal Fest Orlando 2025
